Yes, I have submitted another [PR](https://github.com/apache/iotdb/pull/4873)  for INT 32 and this one is a compliment. Do I need to close the previous PR and just keep this one? If so, I can change the title of this PR. The previous PR didn't pass all the tests. It's a bit weird because I didn't change the code for INT 32.

> For example, if we delete some storage groups or timeseries, some string would be never used but they are always kept in `cachedDevicePool` which cause memory leak.

Hi, it's true that we can't handle the useless string now if we delete some devices. But the `intern()` method is not that fast[1][2] since the purpose of it is to save memory. By comparison, `concurrentHashMap` has a good performance. 
I believe that the situation about deleting timeseries or storage group is relatively few. And we use `deviceIndexMap` when we initialize TsFileResource, when restarting or ingesting data, the performance seems more important. Maybe we need to make a balance here. Or we can delete useless string from `cachedStringPool` manually when time series is deleted instead of just using `intern()`.
What do you think?


[1] https://stackoverflow.com/questions/56203500/java-string-intern-use-hashtable-instead-of-concurrenthashmap
[2] https://www.fatalerrors.org/a/jvm-series-string.intern-performance-of.html

Hi, please create an issue in Jira: https://issues.apache.org/jira/projects/IOTDB/issues/IOTDB-1753?filter=allopenissues
Then this will be added to the release note.

Besides, it's better to add an IT for this case~
LGTM, could you add a new IT or modify an existed one in `IoTDBAggregation*IT` of this special case?
The test cases are LGTM.

Coverage remained the same at 67.741% when pulling **be3054f28588b5ed3ff72f6314a153aee99ddfe5 on czllgzmzl:master** into **7844c63e0e1e20ba741ab3ba8cfb8a086e47fe03 on apache:master**.

> > For example, if we delete some storage groups or timeseries, some string would be never used but they are always kept in `cachedDevicePool` which cause memory leak.
> 
> Hi, it's true that we can't handle the useless string now if we delete some devices. But the `intern()` method is not that fast[1][2] since the purpose of it is to save memory. By comparison, `concurrentHashMap` has a good performance. I believe that the situation about deleting timeseries or storage group is relatively few. And we use `deviceIndexMap` when we initialize TsFileResource, when restarting or ingesting data, the performance seems more important. Maybe we need to make a balance here. Or we can delete useless string from `cachedStringPool` manually when time series is deleted instead of just using `intern()`. What do you think?
> 
> [1] https://stackoverflow.com/questions/56203500/java-string-intern-use-hashtable-instead-of-concurrenthashmap [2] https://www.fatalerrors.org/a/jvm-series-string.intern-performance-of.html

@Alima777, about performance of  `String.intern()`, you can also refer  [this blog](http://java-performance.info/string-intern-in-java-6-7-8/). I have verified the conclusion and got similar result on JDK8. So, it's better to set the `-XX:StringTableSize` when go bad perfromance on `intern()` method. And the performance improved much since JDK11, didn't verify on JDK9.

BTW, memory leak is intolerable in any cases especially in a database server system in my opinion.

> BTW, memory leak is intolerable in any cases especially in a database server system in my opinion.

Hi, I understand your concerns. So what I said is `we can delete useless string from cachedStringPool manually when time series is deleted` to avoid memory leak. I didn't check the conclusion about memory footprint using `WeakHashMap` is 4~5 times than `intern()`, is `concurrentHashMap` still the same?
And `-XX:StringTableSize` still need to be set based on the load of each user, it's not flexible anyway.

> we can delete useless string from cachedStringPool manually when time series is deleted

As far as I know, we can do this by count references to each object like older verion JVM GC does. If we do like this, why don't let JVM help recycle the memory usage by use `WeakHashMap`? Or do you have other ideas?

> `WeakHashMap` is 4~5 times than`intern()`, is `concurrentHashMap` still the same?

The HashMap or ConcurrentHashMap implemented CachePool is wrong without explicit clear, so I didn't verify with them.

Hi, you should know we only use this `cachedStringPool` in limited situation. It's only used in TsFileResource. So count references maybe not needed, we just add it when initialize, and remove it when delete timeseries.

> So count references maybe not needed, we just add it when initialize, and remove it when delete timeseries.

I don't think this way would work. As the strings from `CacheStringPool` are passed to different instances, you must know all of the references of a key are released then the `CacheStringPool` could remove the key. Otherwise, you would hold different instances for same string which will lose the meaning of `CacheStringPool`. 

And for the class, it designs to provide ability like string intern, but has implementation defects. You can't restrict it only used to hold device or measurement path unless you name it something like `DevicePathPool` or `MeasurementPathPool` instead of `CacheStringPool`.

The two ways I can figure out are either use `WeakHashMap<String, WeakRefernce<String>>` instead of `ConcurrentHashMap` or  `String.intern()`. I prefer the later one in the PR.

> memory leak is intolerable in any cases especially in a database server system in my opinion.

+1
